Diagnosed and fixed Cloudflare edge caching serving stale site after deploy
Prefer Tailscale-based SSH deploy to avoid ISP port 22 blocks and GitHub Actions timeouts
Kubernetes lab work: foundations, workloads, now scheduler and multi-node behavior
Document every failure and fix in a searchable knowledge base

summary: Hands-on learning and labs on AWS Free Tier, not formal job experience.
Focused on concepts that transfer: EC2 as a host for containers, networking basics, IAM least privilege, and how the Well-Architected Framework (six pillars) applies to real systems.
handsOn: AWS Free Tier account setup and billing awareness
AWS CLI setup and basic usage (configure, run commands)
Understanding IAM: users, roles, policies, and least privilege
Understanding EC2 as a host for Docker workloads and stable endpoints (e.g. Elastic IP)
Understanding basic networking: VPC, subnets, security groups
CloudWatch logs and metrics at a high level
S3 basics and common use cases (storage, static assets)
AWS Well-Architected Framework: six pillars and how they apply to design decisions

wellArchitectedPillars.name: Operational Excellence
howIApplyIt: Verify with curl and health checks after changes

wellArchitectedPillars.name: Security
howIApplyIt: Prefer Tailscale or tunnels over opening port 22
Use IAM principles in labs; understand roles vs users
Secrets in GitHub Secrets, not in code
Firewall and security group awareness (e.g. UFW)

wellArchitectedPillars.name: Reliability
howIApplyIt: Stable endpoints (Elastic IP, tunnel) so automation does not break
Standard container replace flow: build, stop, rm, run
Verify with curl and service status after deploy
Clean up leftover resources in Kubernetes to avoid routing conflicts

wellArchitectedPillars.name: Performance Efficiency
whatItMeans: Use managed services where they reduce load
howIApplyIt: Use cache headers and purge strategy (e.g. Cloudflare) instead of over-provisioning
Understand when edge caching helps and when it hides deploy issues

wellArchitectedPillars.name: Cost Optimization
howIApplyIt: Understand EC2 and data transfer basics
Self-host where it makes sense; use managed tunnel (e.g. Cloudflare) to reduce exposure and cost

wellArchitectedPillars.name: Sustainability
whatItMeans: Minimize environmental impact by using efficient architectures and scaling to demand
howIApplyIt: Right size resources, use autoscaling where possible, shut down non prod workloads, prefer managed services when they reduce waste

keyLearnings: Debugging Ingress and default-namespace conflicts (e.g. leftover nginx demo serving instead of app)
Cleanup discipline: delete demo resources and verify with kubectl get -A and curl

whatILearned: Docker lifecycle: build, stop, remove, run to replace a container cleanly
Cloudflare edge caching: origin can be updated while the edge serves stale content; purge or cache headers matter
GitHub Actions SSH deploy: verify HOST secret, connectivity, and firewall (e.g. UFW); Tailscale avoids port 22 and ISP blocks
cloudflared running does not prove the app behind it is the right version; verify with docker ps, logs, and curl
lessonsLearned: Site showed old version after deploy: root cause was Cloudflare cache, not Docker. Fix: purge cache or restart cloudflared; verify with curl -I.
Prefer Tailscale-based SSH for deploys when ISP blocks port 22 or GitHub Actions times out.
Standardize container names and use a repeatable deploy script (build, stop, rm, run) so you never leave an old container on the port.
Always verify with curl after deploy; document what "good" looks like (headers, status, content).
